# The Problem

:::: {.inline-fragment}
:::{.fragment}
-   The U.S. is experiencing a mental health crisis (anxiety & depression).\n Access to care is unequal, especially for racial and ethnic minority groups.
:::
:::{.fragment} 
-   Language-based assessments promise scalable screening\n but recent evidence shows reduced performance for minority groups — risking widened disparities.
:::
:::{.fragment}
<a href="https://docs.google.com/document/d/1HglipIcEimjoXzj3AxEaWgLA2uyAOKWmJkqRe-2fgYc/edit?tab=t.0"

   style="display:inline-block;padding:10px 16px;border-radius:6px;background:#197278;color:#fff;text-decoration:none;font-weight:600;">

</a>
:::
::::

# Background
::::{.inline-fragment}
:::{.fragment}
-   Language indexes psychological states (pronouns, negative-emotion words, temporal focus).
:::
:::{.fragment}
-   NLP and LLMs can predict anxiety/depression from text, sometimes matching human sensitivity.
:::
:::{.fragment}
-   Prior work suggests tools perform better for White participants than for some minority groups (Rai et al., 2024).
:::
::::

# Gap in the Literature
::::{.inline-fragment}
:::{.fragment}
-   Limited research testing whether language-based tools (especially modern LLMs) are equally sensitive across racial/ethnic groups.
:::
:::{.fragment}
-   Identify linguistic markers of distress within minority groups to inform equitable tools.
:::
::::

# Aims/Research Questions from Grant
::::{.inline-fragment}
:::{.fragment}
**Aim 1 -- Sensitivty across Groups** - Test prediction of current and future anxiety/depression across four racial/ethnic groups (N_total = 1,600; 400 per group). - **Hypothesis:** Reduced sensitivity for Black, Latino, and Asian participants vs. White participants.
:::
:::{.fragment}
**Aim 2 — Markers in Minority Groups** 
  **- Exploratory/descriptive**: sentiment, pronouns, emotion words, and LLM-derived contextual embeddings to identify group-specific markers.
:::
::::

# Design and Procedures

## Design 

-  Two-session online longitudinal study.
    -   Baseline: open-text responses about mood, motivation, sleep (≈25 min) + GAD-7 + PHQ-8.
    -   Follow-up (1 week): repeat assessments (≈10 min).
    
## Sample
-   N = 1,600 (ages 18–40), balanced by race/ethnicity (White, Black, Latino, Asian).
<!-- -->
-   **Recruitment platform:** Online panel (e.g., Prolific) with demographic quotas.

```{r}
#| paged-print: false
library(ggplot2)
library(patchwork)

# ---- Data ----
timeline_df <- data.frame(day = 1:7)

timeline_df$duration_min <- with(timeline_df,
  ifelse(day == 1, 25,
         ifelse(day == 7, 10, NA_real_))
)

timeline_df$session <- with(timeline_df,
  ifelse(day == 1, "Baseline",
         ifelse(day == 7, "Follow-up", NA_character_))
)
sample_counts <- data.frame(
  race = factor(c("White", "Black", "Latino", "Asian"),
                levels = c("White", "Black", "Latino", "Asian")),
  n = c(400, 400, 400, 400)
)

# ---- Compact theme base size for small output ----
base_size <- 9


p_timeline <- ggplot(timeline_df, aes(x = day, y = 1)) +
  # horizontal baseline from day 1 to 7
  geom_segment(aes(x = 1, xend = 7, y = 1, yend = 1),
               color = "gray60", size = 0.6) +

  # only plot points where duration_min is NOT NA
  geom_point(data = subset(timeline_df, !is.na(duration_min)),
             aes(size = duration_min),
             color = "#197278") +

  # label sessions (only for non-NA rows)
  geom_text(data = subset(timeline_df, !is.na(duration_min)),
            aes(label = session, y = 1.15),
            size = 4, fontface = "bold") +

  # label durations
  geom_text(data = subset(timeline_df, !is.na(duration_min)),
            aes(label = paste0(duration_min, " min"), y = 0.85),
            size = 3.5) +

  scale_x_continuous(breaks = 1:7, labels = 1:7, limits = c(0.5, 7.5)) +
  scale_size_continuous(range = c(4, 8), guide = "none") +

  labs(x = "Day", y = NULL, title = "Study timeline (days 1–7)") +
  theme_minimal() +
  theme(
    axis.text.y = element_blank(),
    axis.ticks = element_blank(),
    panel.grid = element_blank(),
    plot.title = element_text(size = 12, face = "bold",hjust = 0.5)
  )

# ---- Sample counts plot (compact) ----
p_counts <- ggplot(sample_counts, aes(x = race, y = n, fill = race)) +
  geom_col(width = 0.6, show.legend = FALSE) +
  geom_text(aes(label = n), vjust = -0.4, size = 3) +
  scale_y_continuous(expand = expansion(mult = c(0, 0.03)), limits = c(0, 440)) +
  labs(x = NULL, y = "N (participants)", title = "Planned sample by race / ethnicity") +
  theme_minimal(base_size = base_size) +
  theme(
    plot.title = element_text(size = base_size + 1, face = "bold"),
    axis.text.x = element_text(face = "bold", size = base_size),
    axis.title.y = element_text(size = base_size),
    plot.margin = margin(6, 6, 6, 6)
  )

# ---- Combine and save at 4 x 6 inches ----
combined <- p_timeline / p_counts + plot_layout(heights = c(0.9, 1.25))

combined
```

# Measures
::::{.inline-fragment}
:::{.fragment}
-   *Text data: Free-text responses to prompts*\n(e.g., mood, motivation, sleep; e.g., Could you describe your general mood in the past 2 weeks? Has your mood been higher or lower than usual?)
:::
:::{.fragment}
-   *Mental Health Outcomes:* GAD-7 (anxiety), PHQ-8 (depression).
:::
:::{.fragment}
-   *Other covariates:* Age, gender, SES proxies?
:::
:::{.fragment}
-   *Pilot:* N = 240 to validate prompts, retention, and preprocessing pipelines.
:::
::::

# Data processing & Features
::::{.inline-fragment}
:::{.fragment}
**Lexicon-based features:** LIWC categories (I-usage, negative emotion, temporal focus), sentiment scores.
:::
:::{.fragment}
**LLM-based features:** Contextual embeddings from pre-trained/fine-tuned foundation models, Language-based predictions
:::
:::{.fragment}
**Derived DVs / PVs:**

-   DVs: GAD-7 score, PHQ-8 score, \~1-week change.

-   PVs: Lexicon counts (%), sentiment, embedding vectors, demographic variables
:::
::::
# Analyses
::::{.inline-fragment}
:::{.fragment}
-   **Primary Analyses**

    -   Moderation: test race × linguistic-feature interaction predicting GAD-7/PHQ-8
:::
:::{.fragment}
-   **Secondary Analyses**

    -   LLM-based predictions vs. lexicon-based methods

    -   Head-to-head comparisons (e.g., GPT v. LlaMA, vs. BERT embeddings, etc/)

    -   Exploring other NLP Analyses
:::
::::
